Hi,
	Is there any advice people have to offer if I'm going to start some 
serious NEAT coding?

	I want to work in C++ on Windows, but I'll probably want to stay away from 
platform specific issues like user interfaces and graphics output, so I'm 
pretty confident I can keep away from nasty build problems and suchlike 
arising from those.

	My coding style tends towards object-based approaches, templated 
utilities, small classes, inheritance only for clearly defined interfaces, 
STL containers (but not generally streams), lots of asserts and code 
designed to crash rather than vaguely paper over errors....

	Anyway, I'd like to start coding some NEAT-derived experiments.  I'm aware 
that two C++ NEAT implementations exist, but I've no information to choose 
between them.  OTOH, I would be quite happy to start with a written 
specification and write it myself.  I find this is usually the fastest way 
to get into understanding all the dirty details...

	What do people recommend?  Currently I favour starting from scratch, both 
because it will give me a deeper understanding, and also because there have 
been some many interesting new twists and features in recent years.  So if 
I were starting from scratch, I would make sure to update the spec with 
some of the best new innovations, as well as leaving scope for extensions 
with others...

	What do people recommend?

	Which version, if any should I start with?

	Or which statement of the original idea would you take (I know there are 
several ambiguities in the original paper that come up over and again)?

	And which new innovations would you build in (not necessarily as 
_obligatory_ features)?

	Ian "itching to code" Badcoe

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
